revision.text:
'''Lotte Ingrisch''' (born ''Charlotte Gruber''; July 20, 1930 in [[Vienna]]), daughter of Emma and Karl Gruber, is a well known [[Austria]]n author and playwright.
From 1949 to 1965, the author was married to the Austrian philosopher [[Hugo Ingrisch]]. In 1966, she married Austrian composer [[Gottfried von Einem]] (died 1996), for whom she wrote a number of libretti.
During the fifties and sixties, Lotte Ingrisch published some novels under the [[nom de plume]] "Tessa Tüvari".<ref>[http://wien.orf.at/stories/46160/ Wien orf]</ref> From the seventies onward, she became a renowned playwright (stage and radio) and wrote libretti for her husband's operas. A good part of her work has been translated into English, Spanish and other world languages, as shown by worldCat <ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/search?qt=worldcat_org_all&q=%22Lotte+Ingrisch+%22 World Cat]</ref>
==Decorations and awards== * [[Austrian Cross of Honour for Science and Art, 1st class]] (2001)<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.parlament.gv.at/PAKT/VHG/XXIV/AB/AB_10542/imfname_251156.pdf | title = Reply to a parliamentary question | language = German | page=1401 |trans-title=| format = pdf | accessdate = 4 February 2013 }}</ref> * Gold Decoration for Services to Lower Austria (2006)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.onb.ac.at/sammlungen/litarchiv/bestand/sg/nl/ingrisch.htm Lotte Ingrisch documentation in the Austrian Archives of Literature (in German)] ([https://translate.google.com/translate?langpair=de|en&u=http://www.onb.ac.at/sammlungen/litarchiv/bestand/sg/nl/ingrisch.htm&hl=en&ie=ASCII in English]) *[http://wien.orf.at/stories/46160/ Austrian Public Radio & TV portrait on the occasion of Ingrisch' 75th birthday] *[http://www.schule.at/dl/Reisefuehrer.pdf One of Lotte Ingrisch' recent works: Reiseführer ins Jenseits as .pdf-Document (German)] ([https://translate.google.com/translate?langpair=de|en&u=http://www.schule.at/dl/Reisefuehrer.pdf&hl=en&ie=ASCII in English])
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ingrisch, Lotte}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:Austrian dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Recipients of the Austrian Cross of Honour for Science and Art, 1st class]] [[Category:20th-century Austrian women writers]] [[Category:20th-century dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:Women dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:Writers from Vienna]] [[Category:Austrian opera librettists]]

{{For|the CrossFit athlete|Mat Fraser (athlete)}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Mat Fraser | image = Mat Fraser 02A.jpg | imagesize = | caption=Mat Fraser performing in 2008, removing his artificial arms | birth_name = | birth_date = 1962 | birth_place = England | yearsactive = 1980–present | spouse = [[Julie Atlas Muz]] (2012–present) | occupation = [[Musician]], [[actor]] }}
'''Mat Fraser''' is an English rock musician, actor, writer and performance artist. He has [[thalidomide]]-induced [[Phocomelia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/films/100043/Mat-Fraser-Kicking-disability-into-touch |title=Mat Fraser: Kicking disability into touch |date=10 May 2009 |website=[[Daily Express]] |access-date=18 October 2015}}</ref> In 2017, he was cast to play [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]’s [[Richard III (play)|Richard III]] at the [[Hull Truck Theatre]] as part of [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]] City of Culture 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2017/mat-fraser-lead-cast-richard-iii/ |title=Georgia Snow: Mat Fraser to lead cast of Richard III |date=14 March 2017 |website=[[The Stage]] |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref>
== Musical career == Between 1980 and 1995 Fraser was a drummer with several rock bands including "Fear of Sex," "The Reasonable Strollers," "Joyride," "The Grateful Dub," and "Living in Texas," who had a number one single in Italy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pinchbottom.com/performers/mat-fraser/|title=Pinchbottom|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Fraser played the drums with [[Graeae Theatre Company]]'s "Reasons to be Cheerful" at the [[2012 Summer Paralympics opening ceremony|2012 Paralympics opening ceremony]], where he also hosted the pre-televised section,<ref name="FlipStrip">[http://www.timeout.com/london/cabaret/article/3696/flippers-and-strippers-mat-fraser-and-julie-atlas-muz Flippers and strippers – Mat Fraser and Julie Atlas Muz] Time Out London, 31 August 2012</ref><ref name="Paraphilia">[http://www.thisiscabaret.com/from-paraphilia-to-paralympics-with-mat-fraser/ From Paraphilia to Paralympics with Mat Fraser] This is Cabaret, 8 September 2012</ref> and with [[Coldplay]] during the [[2012 Summer Paralympics closing ceremony|closing ceremony]].<ref>[https://www.standard.co.uk/olympics/olympic-news/disabled-drummer-gets-biggest-gig-of-his-life-as-he-joins-coldplay-at-games-finale-8122036.html Disabled drummer gets biggest gig of his life as he joins Coldplay at Games finale] London Evening Standard, 10 September 2012</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/disability-sport/19539113 As it happened: Paralympic closing ceremony] BBC Sport, 9 September 2012</ref>
==Acting career== Fraser left drumming to join [[Graeae Theatre Company]], Europe's leading [[disabled]] theatre company after their production of Ubu inspired him to change careers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://roguesandvagabonds.wordpress.com/2015/04/11/archive-interview-%E2%80%A2-mat-fraser-%E2%80%A2-on-blindness-%E2%80%A2-2004/|title=Rogues and Vagabonds|last=Vernon|first=Sarah|date=2004|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> He worked in forum theatre for Graeae for several months, then landed the part of Dr Prentice in Joe Orton's ''What the Butler Saw''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/1999/mar/03/features11.g29|title=The Guardian|date=3 March 1999|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> He is now a patron of Graeae.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.graeae.org/patrons/mat-fraser/|title=Graeae|date=|website= graeae.org|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Subsequent theatre roles in the '90s included the Group K production of ''Marisol'' and the title role in ''Johnny Sol'' at the Croydon Warehouse.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/people/id/932307/| title= B.F.I.|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
He wrote 2005's ''[[Thalidomide!! A Musical]]'', in which he and Anna Winslet played all the roles.
His first major television role was in the three-part World War II drama series Unknown Soldier (ITV, 1998).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/people/id/932307/|title= B.F.I. Screenonline |date= |website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
In 2009 he appeared in Channel Four's ''[[Cast Offs]]'', a six-part comedy-drama series satirising reality television .<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/6624315/Cameras-love-the-disabled-but-not-disability-says-Cast-Offs-star.html|title=The Telegraph|last=Craig|first=Olga|date=21 Nov 2009|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Fraser has been associated with the use of term "spacking up" to describe when a non-disabled actor plays the part of a disabled person rather than the part going to a disabled actor, as a play on [[blackface|"blacking up",]] used to describe the controversial practice where non-black actors take on the characters of black people. The term was actually coined by one of the show's writers, in the line "spacking up is the new blacking up<nowiki>''</nowiki>.<ref>[http://www.eoinbutler.com/interviews/i%E2%80%99m-a-bit-surprised-to-be-referred-to-as-%E2%80%9Cyou-people%E2%80%9D-isn%E2%80%99t-that-kind-of-condescending/ I’m a bit surprised to be referred to as “you people”… Isn’t that kind of condescending?] EoinButler.com (Irish Times), 6 March 2010</ref>
Fraser has appeared on television in a number of other productions including ''[[Metrosexuality (TV series)|Metrosexuality]]''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0292196/|title=IMDb|date=|website= IMDb.com |publisher= Internet Movie Database |access-date=}}</ref> and ''Every Time You Look at Me''.<ref>{{Cite press release |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2004/03_march/19/every_time.shtml |title= Every Time You Look At Me - a contemporary love story for BBC TWO |date=19 March 2004 |website= BBC.co.uk |publisher= BBC |access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/01/30/theater/newsandfeatures/30schi.html|title=Arms and the Man: The Star of 'The Flid Show'| last= Schillinger |first= Liesl |date=30 January 2005|work=The New York Times|accessdate=21 March 2012}}</ref>
His film ''Kung Fu Flid'' was released in 2009, starring [[Faye Tozer]] (formerly of pop group [[Steps (group)|Steps]]), [[Frank Harper]] and [[Terry Stone]].<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1289414 Kung Fu Flid] at IMDb</ref>
Fraser appeared in the [[RTÉ One]] soap opera ''[[Fair City]]'' in June 2011,<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/features/2011/0607/1224298496087.html Man on a mission] Irish Times, 7 June 2011 {{subscription}}</ref> playing Esther's son [[List of Fair City characters|David]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/tv/faircity/characters/davidosbourn.html |title=David Osbourne played by Mat Fraser |publisher=Raidió Teilifís Éireann |work=Fair City |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110831020757/http://www.rte.ie/tv/faircity/characters/davidosbourn.html |archivedate=31 August 2011 |df= }}</ref>
In 2012 he appeared in [[Kaite O'Reilly]]'s stage play "In Water I'm Weightless" as part of the Cultural Olympiad.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://kaiteoreilly.wordpress.com/2013/03/12/20-questions-mat-fraser/|title=20 Questions: Mat Fraser|last=O'Reilly|first=Kaite|date=March 12, 2013 |website= |publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
Fraser was one of the regular cast members in the fourth season of the US TV series ''[[American Horror Story: Freak Show]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2014/dec/26/mat-fraser-american-horror-story|title=The Guardian|last=Oswell|first=Paul|date=26 December 2014| work= The Guardian |publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
In May 2017, Fraser was cast as Shakespeare’s King Richard III, ‘a disabled guy gets cast as a disabled guy’, a role he discussed with Emma Tracey, presenter for [[BBC Radio]]’s service for disabled people, "Ouch".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p051dzt1 |title= Richard III: A disabled guy gets cast as a disbled guy |date=28 April 2017 |website= [[BBC]] |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref>
In 2018, Fraser was cast in the upcoming [[BBC One]] [[His Dark Materials (TV series)|adaptation]] of [[Philip Pullman]]'s fantasy trilogy [[His Dark Materials]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2018/his-dark-materials |title= BBC and Bad Wolf unveil cast and creative team of His Dark Materials |date=27 July 2018 |website= [[BBC]]}}</ref>
== Television presenting == Fraser was one of the original co-hosts of the [[BBC]]'s ''Ouch! Podcast''.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/ouch/podcast Ouch! It's a disability thing] BBC</ref>
He presented the short-lived Channel Four series "Freak Out"<ref name="Abnormally Funny People">{{Cite web|url=http://www.abnormallyfunnypeople.com/mat-fraser|title=Abnormally Funny People|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
He presented the 2004 Channel Four documentary "Happy Birthday Thalidomide", documenting how the drug was being used in Brazil to treat leprosy, but that its use in a country with low levels of literacy and a black market in drugs was leading to new thalidomide births.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2004/mar/30/lifeandhealth.brazil|title=The Guardian|last=Fraser|first=Mat|date=30 March 2004|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Radio == Fraser played the lead character, Sparky, in BBC Radio Four's Saturday Playhouse production, "Inmates" (1997), by Allan Sutherland and Stuart Morris.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/52bd80623abd43609377c46b56e12e03|title=BBC|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
He was a regular performer on the BBC Radio Four sketch show "Yes Sir, I Can Boogie".<ref name="Abnormally Funny People"/>
== CDs == Fraser has released two rap albums:
"Survival of the Shittest"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Mat-Fraser-Survival-Of-The-Shittest/release/4537250|title=Discogs:Survival Of The Shittest|date=|website=|publisher=Discogs|access-date=17 November 2016}}</ref>
"Genetically Modified...Just For You" (2000)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Mat-Fraser-Genetically-Modified-Just-For-You/release/2961952|title=Discogs:Genetically-Modified Just-For-You|date=|website=|publisher=Discogs|access-date=17 November 2016}}</ref>
== Freak shows == Fraser has shown a continuing interest in freak shows.
His 2001 play 'Sealboy: Freak' draws on the life history of Stanislaus Berent, a sideshow performer with naturally occurring phocomelia who worked under the stage name [[Sealo]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/people/id/932307/|title=B.F.I. Screenonline|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
Fraser's 2002 television documentary "Born Freak" looked at this historical tradition and its relevance to modern disabled performers. This work has become the subject of academic analysis in the field of disability studies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dsq-sds.org/article/view/575/752|title=Disability Studies Quarterly|author1=Mitchell, David |author2=Snyder, Sharon|date=Summer 2005|website=Volume 25, No. 3|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
As part of the documentary, Fraser performed in a Coney Island freak show. He was invited to return to work there professionally and has since worked several summer seasons there.
Fraser's 2011 show, " From Freak to Clique", charted the history of portrayals of disability, including freak show performers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theatermania.com/chicago-theater/news/03-2011/mat-fraser-to-perform-from-freak-to-clique-at-vict_35532.html|title=Theatermania|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
== "Cabinet of Curiosities" == Fraser was commissioned by the Research Centre for Museums and Galleries at the University of Leicester to create a new artistic work, shaped out of a collaborative engagement with museum collections, research and expertise in medical history, museums and disability. The resulting performance, "Cabinet of Curiosities: How disability was kept in a box" was performed at the Thackray Medical Museum, Leeds, the Silk Mill Museum, Derby and Manchester Museum. It won the Observer Ethical Awards, Arts and Culture 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/museumstudies/rcmg/projects/cabinet-of-curiosities|title=University of Leicester|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> The Guardian's Lyn Gardner stated that, "by making a spectacle of himself, Fraser is not only raising the spectre of the Victorian freak show but also subverting it by questioning what is exhibited and what isn't, and making us confront what we are shown and what we are not shown, both in art and in life".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/theatreblog/2014/jan/22/disability-mat-fraser-museum-cabinet-curiosities-theatre|title=The Guardian|last=Gardner|first=Lyn|date=22 January 2014|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Personal life == Fraser married [[Julie Atlas Muz]], a burlesque star, in May 2012 in New York City.<ref name=FlipStrip/><ref name=Paraphilia/>
Mother is actress Paddy Glynn.
Sister is event producer Bimla Safka.
==References== {{reflist|33em}}
==External links== * [http://www.matfraser.co.uk Official website] * {{IMDb name|id=0292196}} * [http://fit-box.xyz/athlete-crossfit.php?id=17 Mat Fraiser] {{Authority control}}

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:⅜.jpg|thumb|200px|Painting by Muhanna Al-Durra]] --> {{Infobox artist | name = Muhanna Durra | image = مهنا دره.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1938 | birth_place =[[Amman]], [[Jordan]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Jordanian | training = [[George Aleef]], Jordan; Academy of Fine Arts, Rome (1958) | movement = [[Orientalism|Orientalist themes]]; [[Cubism]]; abstract art | known_for = Pioneer of Jordanian art movement, introduced cubism to Jordanian art community | influenced by = [[George Aleef]]; William Hallowin | influenced = Princess [[Wijdan Ali]]; Nawal Abdallah | awards = Al-Hussein Decoration | works = }} '''Muhanna Durra''' ({{lang-ar|مهنا دره}}), {{post-nominals|post-noms=[[Order of the Star of Jordan|OSJ]]}}, is a Jordanian painter widely regarded as a pioneer of the Jordanian Arts Movement and for being the first to introduce [[Cubism]] and [[abstract art]] into the Jordanian visual arts community. He is a professor at the Faculty of Fine Art and Design at [[University of Jordan]] and serves as the President of the [[Jordan Association of Fine Arts]].
== Life and career == Born in [[Amman]], [[Jordan]] in 1938 to a [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] father and a Turkish mother,<ref>"Myhana Al Durra" in ''Guide to Jordanian Culture,'' Online: http://www.bourse-des-voyages.com/jordanie/guide-culture-peintres-muhanna-al-durra.php</ref> Al-Dura was raised in a striking red hilltop villa in downtown Amman. The house is only a few blocks away from Amman's popular tourist attraction, the Roman amphitheater, and is commonly believed to rest atop an ancient Roman cemetery. As a child, spooky folklore about his neighborhood sparked a fascination with ghouls and "ignited fantasy in what was beyond the observable, physical world."<ref name="colors">{{cite book|last=Zuhur|first=Sherifa|title=Colors of enchantment: theater, dance, music and the visual arts of the Middle East|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MOVPaLXjjsAC&pg=PA377&dq=Muhanna+Durra&hl=en&ei=4h4cTbKaJM2r8AbgrfCOCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Muhanna%20Durra&f=false|accessdate=30 December 2010|year=2001|publisher=American Univ. in Cairo Press|page=377}}</ref>
A notoriously rebellious youth with a penchant for drawing, he was sent by his father to study art with George Allief (also known as ''[[George Aleef]]''), a former Russian officer with the Tsarist army. Allief taught him the basics of watercolor, drawing and painting, and the European understanding of perspective. These lessons with Allief marked the young artist's transition from childhood drawing to the disciplined work of a professional artist. According to Dura's memoirs, Allief taught his students to meticuoulsy render a matchbox as an exercise in perspective.<ref>Mejcher-Atassi, S. and Schwartz, J.P., ''Archives, Museums and Collecting Practices in the Modern Arab World,'' Routledge, 2016, p.175</ref>
Following the formative years with Allief, the young Muhanna met Dutch painter, William Hallowin, who introduced him to Rembrandt and the Dutch school which sparked an obsession with the power of light. In 1954, he was sent to the [[Accademia di Belle Arti di Roma|Academy of Fine Arts in Rome]] to become the first Jordanian to receive a formal art education.<ref>"Muhanna Durra," in ''The Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Vol. 2, Jonathan M. Bloom and Sheila S. Blair (eds), Oxford University Press, 2009, p.39</ref> He claims to have been disillusioned by the academy and committed himself to studying the classics through art in museums and churches. After graduating in 1958, Durra returned to Amman to teach history of art at the Teachers' Training College. In 1964, Durra established the Fine Arts Section at the Department of Culture and Art, Amman, and then established the Jordan Institute of Fine Arts in 1970. <ref>Mejcher-Atassi, S. and Schwartz, J.P., ''Archives, Museums and Collecting Practices in the Modern Arab World,'' Routledge, 2016, pp 175-76</ref>
Between 1960 and 1970, Al-Durra returned to Rome, where he experimented with abstraction and cubism. In 1970, he returned to Jordan to receive the Kawkab Decoration from King Hussein. <ref>"Muhanna Al Durra," ''University of Jordan Newsletter,'' October, 2017, <Online:http://ju.edu.jo/Lists/NewsLetter/Disp_form.aspx?ID=1418&Issue=October%202017&order=10></ref> Around that time, Durra established an art studio; the first Jordanian to establish an art studio to teach local students.<ref>Zuhur. S., ''Colors of Enchantment: Theater, Dance, Music, and the Visual Arts of the Middle East,'' American University in Cairo Press, 2001, p. 377</ref> Among his notable students was the Princess [[Wijdan Ali]] who is best known for her attempts to revive the traditions of Islamic art.<ref>Hashem Talham, G., ''Historical Dictionary of Women in the Middle East and North Africa,'' Rowman & Littlefield, 2013 p. 24; Zuhur. S., ''Colors of Enchantment: Theater, Dance, Music, and the Visual Arts of the Middle East,'' American University in Cairo Press, 2001, pp 377-78 </ref> Another student was Nawal Abdallah, who is one of the leading lights of Jordan's contemporary arts scene.<ref>Teller, M., "A Hit List of Jordanian Artists" in ''Jordan,'' Rough Guides, 2002, p. 425</ref>
==Work==
Durra is best known for his portraits and also for the way he treated shifting masses of colour.<ref>Teller, M., ''Jordan,'' Rough Guides, 2002, p. 425</ref> He is also acknowledged as the first artist to introduce cubism and abstract art to the Jordanian arts community. <ref>"Muhanna Al Durra," ''University of Jordan Newsletter,'' October, 2017, <Online:http://ju.edu.jo/Lists/NewsLetter/Disp_form.aspx?ID=1418&Issue=October%202017&order=10></ref>
'''Select list of paintings'''
* ''Blue Man Árabe,'' 1966 * ''Cubista Paisaje Urbano,'' 1966 * ''Portrait of Two Women,'' 1975 * ''Composition No. 3,'' oil on canvas, 75 X 95cm, 1977 <ref>Ali, W., ''Modern Islamic Art: Development and Continuity,'' University of Florida Press, 1997, p. 99</ref> * ''Autumn Dew,'' 1981 * ''Old Salti Woman,'' date unknown
==Honours and recognition==
Durra served as a diplomat in Italy, Tunisia, Egypt and later Russia, as Ambassador to the Arab League in Moscow.<ref>Leonov, L., ''The Library Syndrome,'' Walter de Gruyter, 1999, p. 201</ref>
In 2002 the Postal Authorities of Jordan issued a 200 fils postage stamp in honor of Mohanna Durra displaying one of his paintings.
In November 2006 the Ministry of Culture named an art gallery after Muhanna Durra, and held a national symposium about his art with the participation of prominent Jordanian artists and critics.
Other awards include:<ref>Rogers, S., "Muhanna Dura" in ''Mathaf Encyclopedia of Modern Art and the Modern World,'' http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org.qa/en/bios/Pages/Mohanna-Durra.aspx</ref>
* 1965 Decorated Knight of the Holy [[Order of St. Sylvester]] by [[Pope Paul VI]] * 1970 [[Order of the Star of Jordan]] by [[King Hussein]] * 1977 The first State Appreciation Award for his contribution to the cultural development of Jordan * 1978 Golden Medal of the Italian Ministry of Cultural Heritage * 1980 Golden Pioneer Medal and Appreciation Award of the Union of Arab Artists * 1992 Elected active member of the International Informatization Academy * 2006 [[Order of the Star of Italian Solidarity]] * 2008 Distinction of Al-Hussein Decoration from his Majesty King Abdullah II of Jordan (First Order)
==Exhibitions== Durra held numerous solo exhibitions in Rome, Florence, the USSR, various Arab and European capitals, Washington D.C., Plazzo Venezia, the 1988 Venice Biennale Exhibition, and the Fine Arts National Museum of Valletta, Malta. He later held solo exhibitions in Moscow, Saint Petersburg, the Jordan National Gallery of Fine Arts and the Austrian Parliament Central Hall in Vienna.{{cn|date=October 2017}} In 2000, "Muhanna Forever: Pioneer of Modern Art in Jordan" was exhibited at the Jordan National Gallery of Fine Arts and in 2006, he had a solo show at Lines Gallery, Amman, Jordan.<ref>''Mathaf Encyclopedia of Modern Art and the Modern World,'' [Muhanna Durra -Exhibitions, Online: http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org.qa/en/bios/Pages/Mohanna-Durra.aspx</ref>
Durra's work is represented in various national and international collections, including that of the Vatican, the Imperial Court of Japan, the President of the Philippines, Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau of Canada, David Rockefeller, The Jordan National Gallery of Fine Arts, Fannie Mae Bank in Washington, D.C., Bonn City Hall, Washington, D.C. City Hall, the University of San Francisco, Georgetown University, as well as several Jordanian institutes.
==See also== * [[George Aleef]] * [[Islamic art]] * [[Jordanian art]] * [[Jordan National Gallery of Fine Arts]] * [[List of Jordanians]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{ISBN|5-85729-028-7}} by Mohanna Durra, 1998
==Further reading==
Muhanna Durra, ''Muhanna Durra'' [Memoir], Traversa Libra, 1998

page.title: Peter Getting Out of Nick's Pool

revision.text:
{{italic title|noerror|all=yes}} [[File:Peter Getting Out of Nick's Pool.jpeg|thumb|300px|''Peter Getting Out of Nick's Pool'', 1966, David Hockney]] '''''Peter Getting Out of Nick's Pool''''' is an [[Acrylic paint|acrylic]]-on-canvas painting by the British [[pop art]] artist [[David Hockney]], completed in 1966. It depicts the rear view of a naked man climbing out of a swimming pool outside a contemporary house. It is held at the [[Walker Art Gallery]] in Liverpool.
==Background== Hockney moved from England to California in 1964, drawn by its sleek modernist aesthetic and warm [[Mediterranean climate]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.apollo-magazine.com/david-hockney-pool-paintings|title=The pull of Hockney’s pool paintings - Apollo Magazine|date=4 February 2017|publisher=.apollo-magazine.com|accessdate=22 November 2018}}</ref> In 1966, while teaching at [[UCLA]], Hockney met the American art student [[Peter Schlesinger]]. The two became lovers, and Hockney started painting a series of pool pictures, often featuring Schlesinger. A few of these, such as ''Peter Getting Out of Nick's Pool'' (1966), ''[[A Bigger Splash]]'' (1967) and ''[[Portrait of an Artist (Pool with Two Figures)]]'' (1972), later achieved iconic status. On 15 November 2018, the latter set a world record for the most expensive work of art ever sold at auction by a living artist.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/11/16/david-hockney-painting-sells-for-a-record-90-million.html|title=David Hockney painting sells for a record $90 million|first=Chloe|last=Taylor|date=16 November 2018|publisher=cnbc.com|accessdate=22 November 2018}}</ref>
==Description== The painting measures {{cvt|152|x|152|cm|in}}. It depicts the communal pool of the apartment block at 1145 [[Larrabee Street]], Hollywood, north of [[Sunset Boulevard]], which was then the home of art dealer [[Nicholas Wilder]], and shows a naked Schlesinger, then 18 years old, climbing up and out of the pool. Hockney, in his characteristic style, simplifies and flattens the image, and the rippling surface of the water is abstracted into wavy white lines on blue, similar to a comic or an advertisement. The straight lines in the painting were created using [[masking tape]]. The work has a border of un-[[Primer (paint)|primed]] canvas, like a photograph, which Hockney says he left "to make the picture look more like a painting".
The figure in the painting is based on a [[Instant camera|polaroid]] photograph Hockney took of Schlesinger standing up against the hood of his own [[MG Cars|MG car]]. Interviewed about the painting in 2012, Schlesinger laughed about it, saying "That’s why the part under the water isn't painted well—because it was just invented."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/01/27/peter-schlesinger-david-hockney-s-muse-shows-new-works-in-l-a|title=Peter Schlesinger, David Hockney’s Muse, Shows New Works in L.A.|first=Isabel|last=Wilkinson|date=27 January 2012|publisher=thedailybeast.com|accessdate=22 November 2018}}</ref> In 1967, Hockney's painting won the [[John Moores Painting Prize]] at the [[Walker Art Gallery]] in [[Liverpool]]. The painting was acqiuired as a bequest from Sir [[John Moores (British businessman)|John Moores]] who in 1957 established the epomymous biannual award and subsequently often purchased the winning entry and then presented the work to the museum. Moores purchased this work in 1967 and presented it to the museum in 1968. The picture remains in the Walker's permanent collection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/walker/exhibitions/hockney/pool.aspx|title='Peter Getting out of Nick's Pool', David Hockney - Walker Art Gallery, Liverpool museums|website=www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk|accessdate=22 November 2018}}</ref>
==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist}} '''Sources''' * [https://artuk.org/discover/artworks/peter-getting-out-of-nicks-pool-98307 ''Peter Getting out of Nick's Pool''], ArtUK * [http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/walker/johnmoores/history/prizewinners-exhibition/paintings/david_hockney.aspx ''Peter Getting Out Of Nick's Pool'', by David Hockney (born 1937), First prize (Purchase prize), John Moores 6, 1967], Walker Art Gallery * [http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/walker/collections/paintings/20c/item-242744.aspx ''Peter Getting Out of Nick's Pool'', David Hockney, 1966], Walker Art Gallery * [http://www.david-hockney.org/peter-getting-out-of-nicks-pool/ ''Peter Getting Out of Nick’s Pool''], david-hockney.org
{{David Hockney}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Peter Getting out of Nick's Pool}} [[Category:Pop art]] [[Category:Paintings by David Hockney]] [[Category:1966 paintings]] [[Category:British art]] [[Category:Bathing in art]] [[Category:Paintings of the Walker Art Gallery Liverpool]]

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:rochas.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Rochas' Fall 2006 collection.]] --> '''Rochas''' is a [[fashion design|fashion]], [[cosmetics|beauty]], and [[perfume]] house founded in 1925<ref name="place"/> by French designer Marcel Rochas (born 1902, died 1955) the first designer of 2/3-length coats and skirts with pockets.<ref name="telegraph"/> Rochas had been known primarily for its signature perfume, "[[Perfume#Famous perfumes classified by year of creation|Femme]]," which was packaged in a pink box with black [[lace]].<ref name="place">{{cite news|last=Hirschberg|first=Lynn|title=Is There A Place for Olivier Theyskens?|publisher=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/06/magazine/06theyskens.html?ex=1312516800&en=11147b14eed665ef&ei=5088&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss| date=2006-08-06}}</ref><ref name="telegraph"/><ref name="jackets"/>
The company found recent recognition for its [[fashion design]] when it chose [[Olivier Theyskens]] as its [[creative director]] in 2002.<ref name="place"/> (In the years leading to his appointment, its clothes had not been considered notable.<ref name="jackets">{{cite news | last =Hirschberg | first = Lynn| title =The Shape of Jackets to Come| publisher =New York Times | date =2003-11-30 | url =http://www.umsl.edu/~sauter/analysis/creativity/30THEYSKENS.html | accessdate = 2007-03-12 }}</ref>) Theyskens, within his first few months, created an "entirely new silhouette for the house" that was [[France|French]]-influenced and elegant.<ref name="place"/> His first full collection, for Fall 2003, was praised by style.com as "ravishing" and "nothing short of magnificent."<ref name="vogue fall 2003">{{cite web| last =Mower| first =Sarah | title =Rochas Runway Review (Fall 2003)| publisher =Style.com | date =2003-03-06| url =http://www.style.com/fashionshows/collections/F2003RTW/review/ROCHAS | accessdate = 2007-03-12 }}</ref>
For the next several years, Rochas continued to garner praise among fashion critics<ref name="vogue spring 2004">{{cite web| last =Mower| first =Sarah | title =Rochas Runway Review (Spring 2004)| publisher =Style.com | date =2003-10-08| url =http://www.style.com/fashionshows/collections/S2004RTW/review/ROCHAS | accessdate = 2007-03-12 }}</ref><ref name="vogue fall 2004">{{cite web| last =Mower| first =Sarah | title =Rochas Runway Review (Fall 2004)| publisher =Style.com | date =2004-03-03| url =http://www.style.com/fashionshows/collections/F2004RTW/review/ROCHAS | accessdate = 2007-03-12 }}</ref><ref name="vogue spring 2005">{{cite web| last =Mower| first =Sarah | title =Rochas Runway Review (Spring 2005)| publisher =Style.com | date =2004-10-10| url =http://www.style.com/fashionshows/collections/S2005RTW/review/ROCHAS | accessdate = 2007-03-12 }}</ref><ref name="vogue fall 2005">{{cite web| last =Mower| first =Sarah | title =Rochas Runway Review (Fall 2005)| publisher =Style.com | date =2005-03-02| url =http://www.style.com/fashionshows/collections/F2005RTW/review/ROCHAS | accessdate = 2007-03-12 }}</ref><ref name="vogue spring 2006">{{cite web| last =Mower| first =Sarah | title =Rochas Runway Review (Spring 2006)| publisher =Style.com | date =2005-10-05| url =http://www.style.com/fashionshows/collections/S2006RTW/review/ROCHAS | accessdate = 2007-03-12 }}</ref> and to attract loyal followers. Rochas' clients included [[Nicole Kidman]], [[Jennifer Aniston]], [[Kirsten Dunst]], [[Kate Bosworth]], [[Jennifer Lopez]], [[Rachel Weisz]], and [[Sarah Jessica Parker]].<ref name="telegraph"/> In 2006, the [[Council of Fashion Designers of America]] awarded Theyskens the International Award.<ref name="telegraph"/> However, Theyskens' focus on "[[demicouture]]" (special pieces too costly to mass-produce but which may not meet strict [[haute couture|couture]] rules regarding hand-stitching and numbers of fitting) was questioned by fashion insiders as a viable business strategy.<ref name="place"/> His gowns, some of which were priced upwards of $20,000, were often out of reach for all but the most fabulously wealthy.<ref name="place"/> Theyskens took a purer approach to fashion and did not rely (like many fashion houses) on accessory sales and cheaper sister lines for a steady stream of revenue.<ref name="place"/>
In July 2006, Procter & Gamble announced the discontinuation of Rochas' fashion division, shocking many in the fashion industry.<ref name="telegraph">{{cite news |title =House of Rochas suddenly out of fashion| publisher =[[Daily Telegraph]] | date =2006-07-19 | url =https://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/main.jhtml?xml=/fashion/2006/07/19/efrochas19.xml | accessdate = 2007-03-12 | location=London | first=Hilary | last=Alexander}}</ref> One "longtime designer," commenting anonymously in the New York Times, said of the closure, "That sort of perfect, made-to-measure business can't exist today, which is really too bad. Everything is about business now, and fashion shouldn't have to follow normal economic models—that's not the point. What happened to investing in beauty?"<ref name="place"/>
News emerged in 2008 that there were plans to reopen the fashion house.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB122334740444310553?mod=googlenews_wsj | work=The Wall Street Journal | title=P&G Pact to Reopen Rochas Fashion House | first=Ellen | last=Byron | date=2008-10-07}}</ref>
On November 3, 2008, Marco Zanini was named new artistic director for the fashion house.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/28/fashion/designers-of-desire-marco-zanini-at-rochas.html|title=Designers of Desire: Marco Zanini at Rochas|last=Seidler|first=Benjamin|access-date=2018-11-29|language=en}}</ref> He showed his first collection during Paris Fashion Week in February 2009.
About half a century separate Marco Zanini from the creator and founder of the house, Marcel Rochas. Born in 1971, Marco Zanini graduated from the Fine Arts Academy of Milan in 1995. After having been Assistant at [[Dolce & Gabbana]] for their ready-to-wear line, he became [[Donatella Versace]]'s right arm. He then relaunched the American brand of [[Halston]]. Rochas conferred the responsibility of its ready-to-wear collections upon him in 2009. His ambition to build "brick by brick" and season after season the foundations of a renewed House of Rochas, his insistence on making each new collection "unpredictable", confirm the renaissance of Rochas in fashion.
In September 2013, it was confirmed that Zanini would be leaving Rochas after five years with the brand to take on the role of Creative Director at the [[Elsa Schiaparelli| House of Schiaparelli]].<ref>[http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/news-features/TMG10343784/Marco-Zanini-appointed-Schiaparelli-creative-director.html Marco Zanini appointed Schiaparelli creative director], ''Telegraph Fashion'', September 30, 2013</ref> He would be replaced by [[Alessandro Dell'Acqua]] who currently also designs his own line [[No. 21]]. Dell'Acqua's first show for Rochas is set to take place in February 2014.<ref>[http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2013/09/26/alessandro-dell-acqua-replaces-marco-zanini-at-rochas Dell'Acqua Replaces Zanini At Rochas],''Vogue UK'', September 26, 2013</ref>
In 2017 Rochas has made their first foray into menswear. In January the formerly only women's wear oriented label unveiled their first menswear collection, created by French designer Béatrice Ferran. <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.fashionnetwork.com/news/Paris-Fashion-Week-Rochas-unveils-sophisticated-menswear-collection,783506.html#.WV9FU4SGO70|title=Paris Fashion Week: Rochas unveils sophisticated menswear collection|last=Muret|first=FashionNetwork.com, Dominique|work=FashionNetwork.com|access-date=2017-07-07|language=en-UK}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Fashiondesigner|marcel-rochas|Marcel Rochas}} * {{Style.com|rochas}}

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/173.206.155.252|173.206.155.252]] ([[User talk:173.206.155.252|talk]]) to last revision by Citation bot. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Filmmaking sidebar}} [[File:Screenplay example.svg|right|thumb|250px|A page of a screenplay]]
A '''screenplay writer''' (also called '''screenwriter''' for short), '''scriptwriter''' or '''scenarist''', is a writer who practices the craft of [[screenwriting]], writing [[screenplay]]s on which [[mass media]], such as [[film]]s, [[television program]]s and [[video games]], are based.
==Profession== Screenwriting is a [[freelance]] profession. No education is required to become a professional screenwriter, just good [[storytelling]] abilities and [[imagination]]. Screenwriters are not hired employees but contracted freelancers. Most, if not all, screenwriters start their careers writing on speculation (spec) and so write without being hired or paid for it. If such a script is sold, it is called a [[spec script]]. What separates a [[professional]] screenwriter from an [[amateur]] screenwriter is that professional screenwriters are usually represented by a [[talent agent|talent agency]]. Also, professional screenwriters do not often work for free, but amateur screenwriters will often work for free and are considered "writers in training." Spec scripts are usually penned by unknown professional screenwriters and amateur screenwriters.
There are a legion of would-be screenwriters who attempt to enter the [[film industry]], but it often takes years of trial-and-error, failure, and gritty persistence to achieve success. In ''Writing Screenplays that Sell'', Michael Hague writes, "Screenplays have become, for the last half of [the twentieth] century, what the [[Great American Novel]] was for the first half. Closet writers who used to dream of the glory of getting into print now dream of seeing their story on the big or small screen."<ref name=Hauge>{{cite book|last=Hauge|first=Michael|title=Writing Screenplays That Sell}}</ref>
==Film industry== Every screenplay and teleplay begins with a thought or idea, and screenwriters use their ideas to write scripts, with the intention of selling them and having them produced.<ref name="Ferguson 2009">{{cite journal|last=Ferguson|first=Brooks|title=Creativity and integrity: Marketing the "in development" screenplay|journal=Psychology and Marketing|date=17 April 2009|volume=26|issue=5|pages=421–444|doi=10.1002/mar.20281}}</ref> In some cases, the script is based on an existing property, such as a book or person's life story, which is adapted by the screenwriter.<ref>[http://www.screenwriterdude.com/biopic---book-adaptation.html Biopic & Book Adaptation - http://www.screenwriterdude.com/biopic---book-adaptation.html]</ref> The majority of the time, a film project gets initiated by a screenwriter. The initiator of the project gets the exclusive writing assignment.<ref name="Ferguson 2009"/> They are referred to as "exclusive" assignments or "pitched" assignments. Screenwriters who often pitch new projects, whether original or an adaptation, often do not have to worry about competing for assignments and are often more successful. When word is put out about a project a [[film studio]], [[production company]], or producer wants done, they are referred to as "open" assignments. Open assignments are more competitive. If screenwriters are competing for an open assignment, more-established writers usually win the assignments. A screenwriter can also be approached and personally offered a writing assignment.
==Script doctoring== Many screenwriters also work as full or part-time [[script doctor]]s, attempting to better a script to suit the desires of a [[film director|director]] or [[movie studio|studio]]. For instance, studio management may have a complaint that the motivations of the characters are unclear or that the dialogue is weak.
Script-doctoring can be quite lucrative, especially for the better-known writers. [[David Mamet]] and [[John Sayles]], for instance, fund the movies that they direct themselves, usually from their own screenplays, by writing and doctoring scripts for others. In fact, some writers make very profitable careers out of being the ninth or tenth writer to work on a piece, and they often work on projects that never see exposure to an audience of any size. Many up-and-coming screenwriters also [[ghostwrite]] projects and allow more-established screenwriters to take public credit for the project to increase the chances of it getting picked up.
==Development process== After a screenwriter finishes a project, he or she pairs with an industry-based representative, such as a [[film producer|producer]], director, [[literary agent]], entertainment lawyer, or entertainment executive. The partnerships often pitch their project to investors or others in a position to further a project. Once the script is sold, the writer has only the rights that were agreed with the purchaser.<ref name="Ferguson 2009"/>
A screenwriter becomes credible by having work that is recognized, which gives the writer the opportunity to earn a higher income.<ref name="Ferguson 2009"/> As more films are produced independently (outside the studio system), many up-and-coming screenwriters are turning to pitch fests, screenplay contests, and independent development services to gain access to established and credible independent producers. Many development executives are now working independently to incubate their own pet projects.
==Production involvement== Screenwriters are rarely involved in the development of a film. Sometimes they come on as advisors, or if they are established, as a producer. Some screenwriters also direct. Although many scripts are sold each year, many do not make it into production because the number of scripts that are purchased every year exceeds the number of professional directors that are working in the film and [[TV industry]]. When a screenwriter finishes a project and sells it to a [[film studio]], [[production company]], TV network, or producer, he or she often has to continue networking, mainly with directors or executives, and push to have their projects "chosen" and turned into films or TV shows. If interest in a script begins to fade, a project can go dead.
==Union== Most professional screenwriters in the U.S. are [[unionized]] and are represented by the [[Writers Guild of America]]. Although membership in the WGA is recommended, it is not required of a screenwriter to join. The WGA is the final arbiter on awarding [[WGA screenwriting credit system|writing credit]] for projects under its jurisdiction. The WGA also looks upon and verifies film copyright materials.
==See also== * [[Film crew]] * [[First look deal]] * [[Lists of screenwriters]] * [[List of screenwriting software]] * [[Playwright]] * [[Screenwriter's salary]] * [[Script (comics)]] * [[Showrunner]] * [[Television crew]] * [[Television director]] * [[Television program creator]] * [[WGA screenwriting credit system]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{For|use of service marks within Wikipedia|Wikipedia:Manual of Style (trademarks)}} {{Refimprove|date=May 2010}} [[File:Service mark.svg|thumb|250px|A [[fiction]]al [[logo]] using the [[service mark symbol]].]] A '''service mark''' or '''servicemark''' is a [[trademark]] used in the [[United States]] and several other countries to identify a [[Service (economics)|service]] rather than a [[product (business)|product]].For the U.S. definition, see {{cite web|title=15 U.S. Code § 1127. Construction and definitions; intent of chapter|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/15/1127|website=Legal Information Institute|publisher=Cornell Law School|accessdate=12 September 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Larson|first1=Aaron|title=Trademark Law|url=https://www.expertlaw.com/library/intellectual_property/trademark_law.html|website=ExpertLaw|accessdate=12 September 2017|date=7 November 2014}} When a service mark is federally registered, the standard registration symbol [[registered trademark symbol|®]] or "Reg U.S. Pat & TM Off" may be used (the same symbol is used to mark registered trademarks). Before it is registered, it is common practice (with some legal standing) to use the [[service mark symbol]] ℠ (a [[superscript]] SM). The service mark symbol is mapped in [[Unicode]] as {{unichar|2120|Service mark}}.{{cite web |url=https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U2100.pdf |title=The Unicode Standard 7.0, Letterlike Symbols |publisher=Unicode, Inc. }} A Unicode-capable browser is needed to display this character properly, which appears similar to "SM". The HTML entity is ℠. == Usage == A service mark differs from a trademark in that the mark is used on the advertising of the service rather than on the packaging or delivery of the service, since there is generally no "package" to place the mark on, which is the practice for trademarks.{{cite journal|last1=Evans|first1=Lawrence E.|title=Primer on Trademarks and Service Marks|journal=St. Mary's Law Journal|date=1986|volume=18|page=138|url=http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?handle=hein.journals/stmlj18&div=13&id=&page=|accessdate=12 September 2017}} For example, a [[private carrier]] can paint its service mark on its vehicles, such as on planes or buses. Personal service providers can place their service marks on their delivery vehicles, such as on the trucks of [[plumbers]] or on [[moving van]]s. However, if the service deals with communications, it is possible to use a service mark consisting of a sound (a [[sound trademark]]) in the process of delivering the service. This has been done in the case of [[AT&T Inc.|AT&T]], which uses a tone sound followed by a woman speaking the company's name to identify its long distance service; [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|MGM]], which uses the sound of a [[lion]]'s roar; and [[RKO Pictures]], which used a [[Morse code]] signal for their motion pictures. Under United States law, service marks have a different standard of use in order to count as a use in commerce, which is necessary to complete registration and to stop infringement by competitors. A trademark normally needs to be used on or directly in association with the sale of goods, such as on a store display. As services are not defined by a concrete product, use of a service mark on the uniforms or vehicles of service providers or in [[advertisement]]s is instead accepted as a use in commerce. However, like trademarks, service marks must pass a test of distinctiveness for it to be qualified as a service mark.{{cite journal|last1=Howard|first1=Donna L.|title=Trademarks and Service Marks and Internet Domain Names: Giving ICANN Deference|journal=Arizona State Law Journal|date=2001|volume=33|page=637|url=http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?handle=hein.journals/arzjl33&div=23&id=&page=|accessdate=12 September 2017}} For example, [[Dollar-Thrifty Automotive Group|Thrifty, Inc.]] attempted to submit a service mark application that described aspects of their business (uniforms, buildings, certain vehicles) as "being blue." The application was rejected for not being specific enough, and the rejection was upheld on appeal.{{cite web|title=In re Thrifty, Inc., 274 F.3d 1349, 1351 (Fed.Cir.2001)|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=15159379864415021322|website=Google Scholar|publisher=Google|accessdate=12 September 2017}} ==See also== * [[Certification mark]] * [[Marketing]] * [[Service mark symbol]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Trademark law}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Service Mark}} [[Category:Brand management]] [[Category:Brands]] [[Category:Intellectual property law]] [[Category:Product management]] [[Category:Trademark law]] [[Category:Services marketing]] {{typ-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Stanley Carr Boulter''' (29 May 1852 – 5 January 1917) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] lawyer and businessman, who established The [[Law Debenture Corporation]]. In 1902, he married [[Helen Carte]], widow of [[Richard D'Oyly Carte]], and he assisted in the financing of the [[Savoy Hotel|Savoy]] hotel group.
==Education and career== Boulter was educated at [[Clare College, Cambridge]] before being [[called to the Bar]] in 1879.<ref>{{acad|id=BLTR873SC|name=Boulter, Stanley Carr}}</ref><ref name=obit>Obituary: p. 152, ''The Annual Register: a review of public events at home and abroad, for the year 1917''. London: Longmans, Green and Co. 1918.</ref><ref>''The Times'' 28 January 1879, p. 11</ref> During his legal career, he was at one point editor of the Law Reports in ''[[The Times]]''.<ref name=obit/> As a barrister he concentrated on commercial and financial civil cases.<ref>''The Times'', 10 March 1883, p. 6; 18 April 1883, p. 6; 30 April 1883, p. 3; and 4 July 1883, p. 3.</ref> Such criminal cases as he took were generally concerned with fraud and breaches of bankruptcy laws.<ref>e.g., ''The Times'', 16 May 1884, p. 33; and 30 October 1885, p. 14</ref> From 1885 onwards he was sufficiently eminent to appear before the Court of Appeal.<ref>''The Times'', 2 May 1885, p. 5; and 8 July 1885, p. 4</ref>
In 1889, Boulter turned his energies to finance. He was one of the founders of the [[Law Debenture Corporation]], of which he remained the chairman until his death.<ref>[http://www.thesharegallery.co.uk/1939_Law_Debenture.htm The Share Gallery]</ref> He was also chairman of the Imperial Colonial Finance and Agency Corporation, and the New Investment Company.<ref name=tt>''The Times'', 9 January 1917, p. 11</ref> ''[[The Times]]'' called him "one of the leading representatives of the great [[Trust company|Trust Companies]].... Nobody was better than Mr. Boulter at handling a difficult meeting of shareholders ... and restoring confidence."<ref name=tt/>
In politics, Boulter began as a [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]], but disagreed with his party leader, [[William Ewart Gladstone|W. E. Gladstone]], over [[Irish Home Rule bills|Irish home rule]]. Boulter stood unsuccessfully as a "[[Liberal Unionist Party|Liberal Unionist]]" in the general election of 1886,<ref>''The Times'', 8 July 1886, p. 6</ref> and his political views came to be aligned with those of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] party, particularly on any matters affecting the integrity of the [[British empire]].<ref>Boulter, Stanley. "Liberal Votes and the Boers", ''The Times'', 18 October 1900</ref> In social politics he remained more liberal, advocating public assistance for working men to buy homes.<ref>"Municipal aided purchase of artisans' dwellings", ''[[The Observer]]'', 31 July 1894, p. 4</ref> In his later years, he was a [[Justice of the Peace]] for [[Surrey]].<ref name=who/>
==Family== The son of John Boulter of [[Frimley]], Surrey, Boulter first married Edith ''née'' Anderson. There were three sons and four daughters of the marriage.<ref name=who>[http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whowaswho/U193749 " Boulter, Stanley Carr"], ''Who Was Who'', A & C Black, 1920–2008; online edition, Oxford University Press, December 2007, accessed 18 September 2009</ref> Edith died in 1896.<ref>''The Times'', 12 September 1896, p. 1.</ref> In 1902, he married [[Helen Carte]]. Her first husband, [[Richard D'Oyly Carte]], had built and operated both the [[Savoy Theatre]] and [[Savoy Hotel]].<ref>''The Times'', 3 May 1902, p. 1. The wedding took place on 25 April 1902 at [[St Martin-in-the-Fields]].</ref> Boulter used the Law Debenture Corporation to assist in raising funds for expansion of the hotel and was appointed vice-chairman of the Savoy hotel group.<ref>"Mr. Stanley Boulter", obituary, ''The Times'', 8 January 1917, p. 6</ref> After his wife's death in 1913, he continued as vice-chairman and assisted the new chairman, her stepson [[Rupert D'Oyly Carte]], with matters related to the D'Oyly Carte businesses.<ref>''The Times'', 12 November 1915, p. 15</ref>
Boulter died in London in 1917 at the age of 64.
==See also== *[[D'Oyly Carte Opera Company]] *[[Gilbert and Sullivan]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Boulter, Stanley}} [[Category:1852 births]] [[Category:1917 deaths]] [[Category:British barristers]] [[Category:English businesspeople]] [[Category:People associated with Gilbert and Sullivan]] [[Category:Alumni of Clare College, Cambridge]]

{{italic title}} [[File:Les_Premières_funérailles_-_Louis-Ernest_Barrias_(B_837).jpg|thumb]] '''''The First Funeral''''' is an 1878 plaster sculpture by [[Louis-Ernest Barrias]] (1841-1905), first exhibited at the [[Paris Salon]] that year, where it won a medal of honour. He then produced a marble version for the Salon of 1883. Both works showing [[Adam and Eve]] bearing the body of their son [[Abel]]. The plaster original is now in the [[Museum of Fine Arts of Lyon]].
==Sources== *http://www.petitpalais.paris.fr/oeuvre/les-premieres-funerailles

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = The First Grader | image = The First Graderfilm.jpg | image_size = 215px | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Justin Chadwick]] | producer = [[Sam Feuer]]
Richard Harding
Nicola Blacker | writer = Ann Peacock | starring = Oliver Litondo
[[Naomie Harris]]
[[Tony Kgoroge]] | music = [[Alex Heffes]] | cinematography = [[Rob Hardy (cinematographer)|Rob Hardy]] | editing = Paul Knight | studio = [[BBC Films]]
[[UK Film Council]]
Sixth Sense Productions
Origin Pictures
Big Boy Films | distributor = [[National Geographic Entertainment]] | released = {{Film date|df=y|2010|09|04|[[Telluride Film Festival|Telluride]]|2011|05|13|United States|2011|06|24|United Kingdom}} | runtime = 103 minutes | country = United Kingdom
United States
Kenya | language = English | budget = | gross = $714,722 }} '''''The First Grader''''' is a 2010 [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[drama film]] directed by [[Justin Chadwick]]. It stars [[Naomie Harris]], [[Oliver Litondo]], and [[Tony Kgoroge]]. The film is based on the true story of [[Kimani Maruge]], a [[Kenya]]n farmer who enrolled in elementary school at the age of 84 following the Kenyan government's announcement of free universal primary education in 2003.{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/13/movies/the-first-grader-justin-chadwicks-tale-of-kenyan-culture-review.html?ref=movies&_r=0 | title = Simple Quest for Literacy Hits a Wall of Politics | work = A.O. Scott | publisher = [[The New York Times]] | accessdate = 2015-12-17 }} ==Plot== In 2003, a disc jockey announces over a Kenyan radio station that the government is offering free primary school education to all natives who can prove citizenship with a birth certificate. Kimani Maruge (Litondo), an 84-year-old villager, hears this and decides to take it upon himself to seek an education. Arriving at his local school, he meets Jane Obinchu (Harris), the principal and teacher. He expresses his desire to learn how to read. Her teaching colleague Alfred (Munyua), ridicules him and demands he leave. Later, Jane informs her husband Charles (Kgoroge) about Maruge. He discourages her in supporting his educational endeavor. After beginning his initial classes, Maruge is plagued by memories of his service during the [[Mau Mau Uprising]] against the British in the 1950s. He begins to hallucinate and becomes confrontational with the students, struggling to continue his academics. Controversy begins to stir over Maruge’s education. Soon enough, the story that an elderly man going to school becomes national headlines. Mr. Kipruto (Kunene), a superintendent of the school district, is alerted to the situation and strongly disapproves of Maruge's predicament and suggests that he go to an adult educational facility. Meeting with the head of the education board to plead Maruge’s case, Jane is overruled. It is explained to her that if an exception is made to keep Maruge in the school, others will follow, and many schools will eventually become filled with older people sitting aside children. Maruge is forced to attend an adult learning centre, where he soon finds himself surrounded by people with no motivation or ambition to study. Maruge vows to never go back to the adult institution. Jane later decides to offer him a reprieve, to work as her teaching assistant. As Maruge's story gains publicity and attention, the local press descend on the school, causing friction among the parents. The villagers believe Jane and Maruge are seeking fame and fortune at the expense of the children. Following negative feedback and random acts of violence against the school, Jane soon receives a letter that she is to be transferred to another educational institute a few hundred miles away. Jane reveals to Maruge that she is relocating, and then commences an emotional goodbye with the children. Following protests and disobedience on part of the students towards their new teacher, Maruge is motivated to travel to Nairobi to appeal himself to the education board. Jane is reinstated at the school, where Maruge and the children are there to welcome her. The film's epilogue displays a series of graphics stating that at age 84, Maruge is the oldest person to start primary school according to the Guinness Book of World Records. Supplementally, he was invited to make a speech before international leaders at the [[United Nations|UN]] in New York regarding the power of education. He inspired a whole new generation of people to go to school for the first time. Maruge later died in 2009. ==Cast== *[[Naomie Harris]] as Jane Obinchu *Oliver Litondo as [[Kimani Maruge]] *Alfred Munyua as Alfred *[[Tony Kgoroge]] as Charles Obinchu *[[Vusi Kunene]] as Mr. Kipruto *Sam Feuer as American Journalist ==Production== ===Filming=== [[File:Africa6 006.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Great Rift Valley, Kenya|Great Rift Valley]] in Kenya, where filming took place.]] US based film producer [[Sam Feuer]] found the story on the front page of the LA Times and optioned the rights. He, and then, producing partner Richard Harding, partnered with BBC Films and hired Ann Peacock to write the screenplay. The British produced film was shot on location in the [[Great Rift Valley, Kenya|Rift Valley]] in Kenya, despite earlier reports that it would be filmed in [[South Africa]]. Director Chadwick conveyed, "We could have shot it in South Africa, but Kenya has this unbelievable, inexplicable energy inherent in the children, and the people we were making the film about".Interview with director Justin Chadwick, reproduced by Soda Pictures. Theatrical Press Kit. Retrieved 2015-12-15. ==Reception== ===Critical response=== Among mainstream critics the film received generally mixed reviews.{{cite web | url = http://www.metacritic.com/movie/the-first-grader | title = The First Grader | work = CNET Networks | publisher = [[Metacritic]] | accessdate = 2015-12-15 }} [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gave the film a fresh score of 60% based on reviews from 71 critics, with an average score of 5.6 out of 10.{{cite web | url = http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_first_grader/ | title = The First Grader (2010) | work = IGN Entertainment | publisher = [[Rotten Tomatoes]] | accessdate = 2015-12-15 }} At [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[weighted mean|weighted average]] out of 100 to critics' reviews, ''The First Grader'' was given a score of 56 based on 21 reviews. ==See also== *[[2010 in film]] *[[Mau Mau Uprising]] ==References== ;Footnotes {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.thefirstgrader-themovie.com/}} * {{IMDb title|0790663|The First Grader}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|the_first_grader|The First Grader}} * {{metacritic film|the-first-grader|The First Grader}} * {{mojo title|firstgrader|The First Grader}} {{Justin Chadwick}} {{DEFAULTSORT:First Grader}} [[Category:2010 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:British biographical films]] [[Category:British drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American biographical films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:Kenyan films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films set in Kenya]] [[Category:Films set in 2003]] [[Category:Films shot in Kenya]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:BBC Films films]] [[Category:Films about education]]

{{Infobox website | name = UbuWeb | logo = | logocaption = | screenshot = | collapsible = | collapsetext = | caption = | url = {{URL|www.ubu.com}} | slogan = | commercial = no | type = [[Digital library]] | registration = none | language = English | num_users = | content_license = | owner = | author = | editor = [[Kenneth Goldsmith]] | launch_date = <!--{{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}}--> | alexa = 126,002 ({{As of|2018|06|lc=y}})<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/ubu.com|title=ubu.com Site Info |publisher=[[Alexa Internet]], Inc |accessdate=24 June 2018}}</ref> | revenue = | current_status = Online | footnotes = }}
'''UbuWeb''' is a large web-based educational resource for [[avant-garde]] material available on the internet, founded in 1996 by poet [[Kenneth Goldsmith]]. It offers [[visual poetry|visual]], [[Concrete poetry|concrete]] and [[sound poetry]], expanding to include [[film]] and [[sound art]] [[mp3]] archives.
==Philosophy==
UbuWeb was founded in response to the marginal distribution of crucial [[avant-garde]] material. It remains [[non-commercial]] and operates on a [[gift economy]].<ref>Kenneth Goldsmith, [http://epc.buffalo.edu/authors/goldsmith/ubuweb.html "Ubuweb Wants to be Free" Open Letter], 2001</ref> UbuWeb ensures educational open access to out-of-print works that find a second life through [[digital art]] reprint while also representing the work of contemporaries. It addresses problems in the distribution of and access to intellectual materials.
==Distribution policy==
UbuWeb does not distribute commercially viable works but rather resurrects [[avant-garde]] [[sound art]], [[video]] and textual works through their translation into a [[digital art]] web environment - re-contextualising them with current academic commentary and contemporary practice.<ref>[[Damon Krukowski]], "[http://epc.buffalo.edu/authors/goldsmith/artforum.html Free Verses: Kenneth Goldsmith and UbuWeb]", ''[[Artforum]]'', March 2008</ref> It houses and distributes freely the entire archive of the [[Tellus Audio Cassette Magazine]] project.
==Content==
Beyond its repository of works, UbuWeb features curated sections including [http://www.ubu.com/ubu/ ''/ubu Editions''] book-length editions of contemporary [[poetry]], selected and introduced by the poet Brian Kim Stefans. [http://www.ubu.com/ethno/ ''UbuWeb: Ethnopoetics''], curated by [[Jerome Rothenberg]], is fusing the avant-garde with traditional ethnic practices. [http://www.ubu.com/papers/ ''UbuWeb: Papers''] a series of contextual academic essays. [http://www.ubu.com/outsiders/ ''UbuWeb:Outsiders''] considers the legitimization of Outsider works and features [http://www.ubu.com/outsiders/365/index.html ''The 365 Days Project''] curated by Otis Fodder.
==Infrastructure==
UbuWeb is not affiliated to any academic institution, instead relying on alliances of interest and benefiting from bandwidth donations from its partnerships with [https://web.archive.org/web/20060715105639/http://greylodge.org/gpc/ GreyLodge], [[WFMU]], PennSound, The Electronic Poetry Center, The Center for Literary Computing, and ArtMob.
UbuWeb's board of directors includes the poets [[Charles Bernstein]], [[Darren Wershler-Henry]] and critic [[Marjorie Perloff]].
